title: Exposed: new web banking savings gap - many top deals only on offer to customers who can go online
text:
Millions of older savers who do not use the internet are being abandoned by some banks and building societies.

A stream of new easy-access deals offering top rates are only available to those happy to manage their accounts online.

It means they are off-limits to those who need to pay in cash or cheques, do not own a computer or simply don't feel comfortable using the internet.

Left behind: A stream of new easy-access deals offering top rates are only available to those happy to manage their accounts online

Surprisingly, two of these online-only deals come from building societies which, unlike banks, pride themselves on their branch networks.

The list also includes the trusted Saga brand, which specialises in providing financial services for the over-50s. It now requires savers to have an email address.

There are more than 1 million households with at least one adult over the age of 65 which have no internet access, according to Office for National Statistics figures. And 7 million over-65s have not used internet banking in the past three months.

Yet while the top online easy-access account currently pays 1.46 per cent, you'll get as little as 0.1 per cent on the High Street. The 1.36 percentage points difference means £136 less interest a year on each £10,000.

For example, HSBC pays 0.15 per cent on its Flexible Saver, which is dropping to 0.1 per cent in December. NatWest offers 0.2 per cent on balances up to £25,000 and 0.3 per cent up to £1 million on its Instant Saver. Barclays pays up to 0.3 per cent on its Everyday Saver, Halifax Instant Saver and Lloyds Standard Saver 0.2 per cent, and Santander Everyday Saver 0.35 per cent.

Even branch users who hunt out better deals can still lose out. Britain's biggest building society, Nationwide, pays 0.41 percentage points less to customers who want to use its branches rather than save online.

Its one-year Triple Access Saver, launched earlier this month, pays 1.21 per cent and limits you to three withdrawals a year. But it's only available online at this rate of interest.

Open the account through a branch and you are fobbed off with a much lower 0.75 per cent.

Leeds BS new Limited Issue Online Access Cash Isa is also out of bounds for those who don't use the internet. At 1.4 per cent it offers one of the top tax-free cash Isa rates on £1,000 or more. But if you want a branch-based account, you are paid a lower 1.3 per cent on its Double Access Cash Isa.

Unlike the online account, this also limits you to two withdrawals a year and you must keep at least £5,000 in the account.

Yorkshire BS also reserves the 1.4 per cent rate on its 1 Year Limited Access Saver to online savers.

Its similar branch account Annual Access pays a lower 1.3 per cent. Both accounts also restrict you to making withdrawals on just one day a year.

The new Saga Easy Access account pays 1.4 per cent with no withdrawal restrictions.

The over-50s specialist has teamed up with global financial giant, Goldman Sachs International, to offer the account.

You can operate it online or by phone — but you still need an email address to open it. Saga says the email address is an important part of the security checks Goldman Sachs uses to protect a customer's accounts. But some providers have taken a different approach. The new Triple Access Saver from Coventry BS pays the same 1.46 per cent whether you open and run it online, through the post or by visiting its branches.

You are limited to three withdrawals a year and the rate includes a 0.31 percentage point bonus payable until 2021.

Online provider, Charter Savings Bank has opened up a postal version of its Easy Access Account after research pinpointed demand from savers. It offers a simple savings account with no withdrawal restrictions and no bonus. The rate is 1.35 pc on a minimum £5,000.

You add to your account by electronic transfer or a cheque from the account you elect to link to your savings.

Kent Reliance pays 1.43 per cent through its Easy Access account if you open it online or through its limited branch network — or 1.3 per cent if you run it through the post.

Money is pouring into easy-access accounts as savers, nervous of what will happen to interest rates, keep their money to hand rather than tying it up in fixed-rate bonds.

Nearly £9 out of every £10 in easy-access accounts is sitting with the big banks, trusted by older savers.

These big institutions hold £664 billion of our savings in easy-access accounts out of a total £759 billion.
